results.title: Mouse-activated candle lighter
results.creator_credit: Prism Productions and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description: The mouse-activated candle lighter illustrates various forms of potential and kinetic energy. It is made from a mousetrap, fishing rod, alarm clock, ice-pack, train motor, rubberband, match and candle. Students are challenged to find the many forms of energy hidden in the mechanism and their movements. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Mountains, materials and technology
results.creator_credit: London Television Service, Bob Thorpe and Mike Lockey
results.brief_description: Examines some of the latest developments to help people survive in hostile environments. Discusses the manufacture of new fabrics which have been used to design a new generation of tents, clothing and sleeping bags for surviving high altitude conditions. Also looks at how the use of a global positioning system can be used to help the lives of people stranded at sea or on land.

results.title: Mountains of the moon
results.creator_credit: Daniel Melnick, Indieprod and Bob Rafelson
results.brief_description: In the 1850’s, two British officers, Captain Richard Burton and Lieutenant John Hanning Speke, set out on a spectacular adventure to discover the source of the Nile. As they pushed deeper and deeper into the hitherto unexplored regions of the African wilderness, they forged strong bonds of friendship in order to survive the great dangers which befell them. It was ironical then, that a friendship which had endured so much in Africa, was ultimately destroyed by the rigidity and competitiveness of Victorian England and its aristocracy. Burton, played by Patrick Bergin, is a larger than life character; a “maverick” geographer whose love affair and marriage to Isabelle, (Fiona Shaw), was “the stuff from which legends were made”. Speke, (Iain Glen), was the son of an aristocrat, bound by the strict conventions of his time. Together they embarked on one of the greatest explorations in history. Divided, their friendship in tatters, and their reputations in jeopardy, Speke ended his life tragically, and Burton quit England.

results.title: Mountains of adventure
results.brief_description: A fascinating documentary looking at two very different mountain ranges and how they are conquered by a small group of Aussie adventurers. The group flew to India to trek into the hidden kingdom of Zanskar, far north of Delhi through the highlands, to altitudes over 10,000 feet above sea level. They then rafted down white water rapids to Shingo La Pass at the Zanskar - before travelling to Kashmir. The second leg of this extraordinary journey took them to the New Zealand Alps, where they were caught in the worst weather experienced on Mount Victoria over 45 years. An amazing rescue sequence follows.

results.title: Mountain sanctuary
results.brief_description: In Western Tasmania, rugged mountain peaks and secret Alpine lakes beckon the bush walker and mountaineer. Explores thoroughly the beautiful Tasmanian highlands where unique flora and fauna, including Tasmanian devils, wombats, native cats, and black swans are found.

results.title: Mountain People
results.brief_description: Contrasts lifestyles of the Swiss people of Guarda and the Gurungs of Nepal. Looks at the way in which people isolated by mountains retain their cultures and way of life. No other credits available.

results.title: Mountain music
results.creator_credit: Will Vinton Productions and Will Vinton
results.brief_description: A 3-D animated film portraying the impact of modern technology on the planet. The happy and tranquil life of forest creatures is changed by three musicians whose amplified sounds, cause the eruption of a mountain. Animated by Bevan Vinton, Bob Gardiner and Will Vinton. Featuring Kath Hendrickson. Music by Bill Scream and Paul Jameson.

results.title: Mountain man
results.creator_credit: Ford Film Unit and Terry Ohlsson
results.brief_description: The 1964 Monte Carlo rally seen through the eyes of champion rally driver Vic Elford. With his partner David Stopne, driving a Cortina, Elford emerged from hazards of dust and fog, blinding sunlight and driving rain as winner of the touring category, with a class victory and a coveted Coupes des Alpes.

results.title: Mountain lands in jeopardy
results.brief_description: The soil erosion caused by introduced animals in the mountains of New Zealand. The vegetation in the alpine country around the head-waters of the Waitake River has been destoryed by deer, hare and thar. Burning off the natural tussock to create sheep pasture has added to the problem. Erosion and flooding of valley farms has resulted.
